metadata.title: AI Vocabulary Quiz
metadata.description: A comprehensive quiz on AI terminology and concepts

questions.question: What does 'GPT' stand for in GPT-4?
questions.explanation: GPT stands for Generative Pre-trained Transformer, a type of neural network architecture.

questions.question: What is a 'hallucination' in the context of AI?
options: When AI generates false or nonsensical information
A type of neural network architecture
The process of training AI models
A method for improving AI accuracy
questions.explanation: AI hallucination refers to when AI systems generate information that is factually incorrect or nonsensical.

questions.question: What does 'RAG' stand for in AI systems?
questions.explanation: RAG combines retrieval of relevant information with generative AI to improve accuracy and reduce hallucinations.

questions.question: What is 'fine-tuning' in machine learning?
options: Adapting a pre-trained model for a specific task
questions.explanation: Fine-tuning involves taking a pre-trained model and training it further on task-specific data.

questions.question: What does 'LLM' stand for?
questions.explanation: LLM stands for Large Language Model, referring to AI models trained on vast amounts of text data.

questions.question: What is 'prompt engineering'?
options: Designing effective inputs for AI models
questions.explanation: Prompt engineering is the practice of crafting effective prompts to get better responses from AI models.

questions.question: What is 'overfitting' in machine learning?
options: When a model performs well on training data but poorly on new data
Training a model for too long
questions.explanation: Overfitting occurs when a model learns the training data too well and fails to generalize to new, unseen data.

questions.question: What does 'NLP' stand for?
questions.explanation: NLP stands for Natural Language Processing, the field focused on helping computers understand human language.

questions.question: What is a 'neural network'?
options: A computing system inspired by biological neural networks
questions.explanation: Neural networks are computing systems inspired by biological neural networks that process information.

questions.question: What is 'gradient descent'?
options: An optimization algorithm to minimize error
A type of neural network layer
questions.explanation: Gradient descent is an optimization algorithm used to minimize the loss function during model training.

questions.question: What is 'computer vision'?
options: AI that can interpret and understand visual information
A method for compressing video files
questions.explanation: Computer vision enables AI systems to interpret and understand visual information from the world.

questions.question: What is 'reinforcement learning'?
options: Learning by repeating the same task
Learning through trial and error with rewards and penalties
questions.explanation: Reinforcement learning involves an agent learning through trial and error, receiving rewards for good actions.

questions.question: What does 'API' stand for in the context of AI services?
questions.explanation: API stands for Application Programming Interface, allowing different software applications to communicate.

questions.question: What is 'transfer learning'?
options: Using knowledge from one task to help with another task
questions.explanation: Transfer learning applies knowledge gained from one task to improve performance on a related task.

questions.question: What is 'deep learning'?
options: Machine learning using neural networks with many layers
Learning from large amounts of data
questions.explanation: Deep learning uses neural networks with multiple layers to model complex patterns in data.

questions.question: What is 'AGI'?
questions.explanation: AGI refers to Artificial General Intelligence, AI that matches or exceeds human intelligence across all domains.

questions.question: What is 'supervised learning'?
questions.explanation: Supervised learning uses labeled training data to learn patterns and make predictions.

questions.question: What is 'unsupervised learning'?
options: Finding patterns in data without labels
questions.explanation: Unsupervised learning finds hidden patterns in data without using labeled examples.

questions.question: What is a 'token' in NLP?
options: A unit of text processed by the model
questions.explanation: In NLP, a token is a unit of text (like a word or subword) that the model processes.

questions.question: What is 'bias' in AI systems?
options: A preference for certain data formats
Unfair treatment of certain groups in AI decisions
The cost of running AI models
questions.explanation: AI bias refers to unfair or discriminatory treatment of individuals or groups by AI systems.

questions.question: What is 'training data'?
options: Data used to test model performance
Data used to teach the AI model
questions.explanation: Training data is the dataset used to teach an AI model during the learning process.

questions.question: What is 'model inference'?
options: Using a trained model to make predictions
questions.explanation: Model inference is the process of using a trained AI model to make predictions on new data.

questions.question: What is 'explainable AI' (XAI)?
options: AI that can explain its decisions and reasoning
questions.explanation: Explainable AI focuses on making AI decisions transparent and understandable to humans.

questions.question: What is 'federated learning'?
options: Training models across distributed devices without centralizing data
questions.explanation: Federated learning trains AI models across decentralized devices without sharing raw data centrally.

questions.question: What is 'edge computing' in AI?
options: Computing at the very latest technology
Running AI computations on local devices rather than in the cloud
Computing at the edge of networks
questions.explanation: Edge computing in AI involves running AI computations locally on devices rather than in remote data centers.
